project.teaser: Political trust has long been regarded as an important element of regime support and factor of regime stability; it is widely associated with a number of positive outcomes in representative democracies. Political trust drives citizens interest and engagement in politics...
project.objective: Political trust has long been regarded as an important element of regime support and factor of regime stability; it is widely associated with a number of positive outcomes in representative democracies. Political trust drives citizens interest and engagement in politics, increases voting turnout and makes law-abiding behavior more common. Political trust is frequently equated to diffuse regime support and thus linked to the effective functioning and stability of the political system. The proposed research effort will monitor the structural (long-term) drivers of political trust but also emphasize the strategies which can be employed by diverse actors and agencies to strengthen accurate and informed judgments of agency trustworthiness. The objective of this ambitious project is twofold. First, we aim to design and implement a complex research effort to collect comprehensive evidence on the judgments of trustworthiness in a range of European states. Second, the project will develop a comprehensive and transparent toolbox of short-term and long-term policy interventions including recommendations, and methodologies for enhancing trust in political institutions, boosting transparency, and inclusiveness of representative systems in Europe. While there is a growing concern about the crisis of democracy and democratic backsliding, this research effort will provide an innovative theoretical perspective on the sources of regime support and strategies for trust building in the public domain. The project looks at the different drivers of 'positive high trust in democracy' and 'negative high trust in autocracy'. The project will facilitate development of a new paradigm of political trust and trust-building and will inspire emergence of new insights on the multi-facet origins of political trust and multi-factor nature of trustworthiness. The project has partners in Austria, Czechia, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Sweden, and Ukraine.
project.title: Trust in European Democracies
project.keywords: Trust in government, in parliament, legal system, media system, political parties, interest groups, NGOs, support for democracy, voting behavior, political inclusion, political integration

result.title: Database “Long-term trends of political polarization” (1990-2022)
result.description: D5.2. Electronic database: electronic database comprising a broad scope of quantitative indicators for the comprehensive assessment of political polarization across the EU member-states for 1990-2022. The database will be made available in free public access via the project website as well for downloading in SPSS, SAS, R, Stata, csv formats. Delivered in month 10; regularly updated till the end of the project and after that.

result.title: Project newsletter
result.description: D11.2. Project newsletter and subsequent updates - information update for project members and subscribers, members of advisory boards, followers. The newsletter will be distributed via MailChimp with the free subscription open to all interested persons and organizations. The newsletter will be sent out on the quarterly basis; special issues might be created and distributed on the ad-hoc basis.

result.title: Communication, Dissemination, Exploitation Plan
result.description: D11.1. Dissemination, Communication and Exploitation Plan will list all project communication and dissemination activities and events, their timing, format and location. Disseminations tools and their management to be outlined in the dissemination plan include online (website, social media) and onsite communication activities (meetings with academia, policymakers, CSO leaders); electronic (e-newsletter, infographics) and printed promotion materials (brochure, flyer); plan for TRUEDEM own dissemination events, including policy-drafting workshops, findings presentation at high-level EU conferences and participation in external dissemination opportunities. The plan, first delivered in month 3, will be updated on the quarterly basis.

result.title: Literature review on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on democratic attitudes and trust
result.description: D3.1. Literature review on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on democratic attitudes and trust: survey of the existing literature outlining main implications the corona-pandemic has had for the pro-democratic attitudes and trust in Europe, including possible mediators of this influence.

result.title: Set of infographics on European and National elections
result.description: D2.2. Set of infographics on European and National elections: data on the mid- to long-term trends in voters’ turnout transformed into a set of infographic materials produced in different European languages and prepared for all EU member-states. The infographics will be distributed as a part of project dissemination effort in workshops and conferences.

result.title: Voter turnout in Europe (1990-2022)
result.description: D2.1. Voter turnout in Europe (1990-2022): longitudinal cross-country quantitative database featuring official data of the European and national election results for EU member states. Distributed through the project website in free access, including for downloading in SPSS, Stata, SAS, R, and csv formats.

result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: D12.2. Data Management Plan (DMP) comprises a set of special procedures to collect, process and manage data tailed to the TRUEDEM research objectives and tasks and developed in strict accordance with the respective EU and national laws and ethical requirements. The plan will cover procedures involving analysis of secondary survey data and collection of primary human data that may involve sensitive personal data. The DMP will apply to all researchers of the TRUEDEM consortium. The plan for data-handling will include aspects such as: (1) data safety procedures which are compliant with privacy by de-sign and protection of confidentiality (including GDPR); (2) procedures for quantitative and qualitative data collection, storage, protection, retention, transfer if any, destruction or reuse; (3) metadata documentation, expected schedule for data access, data limitations for secondary use, data repository/sharing/archiving; (4) procedures related to the data employed for secondary data analysis; (5) choice of data, sharing and ownership of data, choice of software; (6) use of methods when observing participants; (7) roles and responsibilities of project staff in the management and retention of data.

result.title: Political Culture: Trust and Regime Support in the Black Sea Region
Electronic database “Long-term trends of political trust dynamics” (1980-2022)
result.description: D1.3. Electronic database “Long-term trends of political trust dynamics” (1980-2022): a dataset of quantitative indicators of political trust in Europe from 1980s to the present time. The dataset, first procured in month 12 and updated through the course of the project, will be freely available through the project website. The data-set will be available as a web resource, but also for downloading in SPSS, Stata, SAS, R, and csv.

result.title: Existential insecurity and deference to authority: the pandemic as a natural experiment
Methodological paper on trust data harmonization
result.description: D1.2. Methodological paper on trust data harmonization: methodological paper will discuss existing techniques to harmonize data on trust. With the data originating from various sources, collected using different measures and indicators, before the data can be employed in a comparative analysis, harmonization is required. Procedure of harmonization is highly valuable in Social Sciences as it allows to expand the existing data-bases, allowing to combine different types of data-sets.

result.title: How Active and Passive Social Media Engagement on Facebook and Instagram Shapes Democratic Attitudes Among Users in Slovakia
Literature review on the impact of the migration and refugees’ waves on democratic attitudes and trust
result.description: D3.2. Literature review on the impact of the migration and refugees’ waves on democratic attitudes and trust: survey of the existing literature outlining main implications the economic migration and refugees movement have had on the pro-democratic attitudes and trust, including possible mediators of this influence. Delivered in month 12.

result.title: Printed dissemination materials
result.description: D11.3. Printed materials - leaflets, posters, roll up banners as well as printed editions of project analytical and scientific deliverables (infographics, policy briefs, educational materials, special issues). Exact schedule of production of the printed information and dissemination materials will be outlined in the dissemination plan. The ICSR-AT will be responsible for the production of such materials in English while all project participants will be encouraged to produce translations in their national languages.

Methodological framework paper on identities and polarization
result.description: D5.1. Methodological framework paper: methodological framework paper will elaborate the theoretical and methodological approach to the analysis of identities and polarization as well as the state of the art and scope of relevant issues to be addressed. Delivered in month 9.

result.title: Il declino della partecipazione al voto. Compagno al duol…(non) scema la pena
Ethics Plan
result.description: D12.3. Project Ethics Plan comprises a set of provisions, procedures and requirements aimed to ensure that all research, disseminating and policy-related activities carried out within the TRUEDEM research plan do comply with ethical principles and relevant national, EU and international legislation, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights and its Supplementary Protocols. Particular focus will be made on meeting the principles of proportionality, the right to privacy, the right to the protection of personal data, the right to the physical and mental integrity of a person, the right to non-discrimination and the need to ensure highlevels of human health protection. Project ethics plan shall concern both consortium participants themselves, project participants (experts and general public) involved as informants, and stakeholders who participate as users of the project outputs.

result.title: “Rally around the flag” effects in the Russian–Ukrainian war
Periodic Reporting for period 1 - TRUEDEM (Trust in European Democracies)
result.teaser: There is widespread concern among many scholars, media commentators, and policymakers that public trust in political leaders and democratic institutions has eroded over time, within Europe and elsewhere, due to public disaffection with how leaders and institutions perform...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
